title: Tuesday, 8th November, 2016
bodyHTML:
11:02 am
PM

Morning!

PM

You'll note that Cardiff ceased control of the Further Reading slot overnight

PM

http://ftalphavill...on-day-and-beyond/

11:02 am
PM

With hilarious results

PM

Before we get on, couple of things to note.

PM

1. This will be a short ML session. Prob just 30 mins

11:04 am
PM

Aside from the election overshadowing everything (or people trying to use it as a shadow), we hae a bit of a development crisis to sort with AV2

PM

2. Cardiff, Alex and Matt will be running a FastAV election show here at Alphaville, starting around 5pm ET

PM

10pm London time

11:05 am
PM

So you can come back from the pub and log on for our alternative take

PM

thumbs up

PM

But in the meantime, let's see what's going on in London

11:05 am
PM

And give you a pic for today

undefined
PM

11:06 am
BE

Who she?

PM

Jo Moore

PM

Cos we have a true Jo Moore moment this morning

11:06 am
PM

If you don't know who Jo Moore is, go: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jo_Moore

BE

Oh, right. Good day to bury bad news woman.

PM

On the day of the US election, when everything is hanging in the balance and all newsrooms in the UK are pointed at Washington DC, we get....

11:07 am
PM

This statement provides an update on the Financial Conduct Authority’s (FCA) review of Royal Bank of Scotland’s (RBS) treatment of small and medium enterprise (SME) customers in financial difficulty.

PM

I mean, what the hell?

PM

And

11:08 am
PM

RBS Launches a New Complaints Process and Refund of Complex Fees for SME customers in GRG

PM

Taken eight years for them to get round to this

PM

We're numb to it all

11:09 am
PM

But i think it's pretty scandalous

Royal Bank of Scotland Group PLC (RBS:LSE): Last: 183.70, down 2.8 (-1.50%), High: 187.10, Low: 183.33, Volume: 7.59m
PM

Market numb to it all as well

11:09 am
PM

Anyway, you can read the RBS stuff here: http://www.investe...1611080700125806O/

BE

Or direct from the FCA here: https://www.fca.or...estructuring-group

PM

The FCA have largely cleared them

11:10 am
PM

RBS did not set out to artificially engineer a position to cause or facilitate the transfer of a customer to GRG;

• SME customers transferred to GRG were exhibiting clear signs of financial difficulty;

• there was not a widespread practice of identifying customers for transfer for inappropriate reasons, such as their potential value to GRG, rather than their level of distress;

• there was not a widespread practice of requesting personal guarantees and/or cash injections when GRG had already determined that it had no intention of supporting such businesses;

• there was not a widespread practice of RBS making requests for information from customers that were unnecessarily burdensome;

• there was not a widespread practice of RBS acting as a “Shadow Director”;

• there was no evidence that an intention for West Register to purchase assets had been formed prior to the transfer of the customer to GRG; and

• there were no cases identified where the purchase of a property by West Register (as opposed to by another person) alone gave rise to a financial loss to the customer.

PM

Really?

BE

The possibility remains of further sanctions, though. FCA says, because it's an unregulated business, its powers are limited.

11:12 am
BE

Anyway, RBS gets another £400m to add to its endless cascade of liabilities

BE

Which is nearly irrelevant, because it's a cascade and it's endless.

PM

hehehe

11:12 am
PM

So true

PM

So let's move on

undefined
11:13 am
PM

Footsie flat

PM

But there's a string of figures/trading statements

PM

Which do we start with?

11:13 am
BE

Yeah, there's a lot of results news around. So let's not start there.

PM

OH, ok

BE

Instead, let's start with EasyJet. Again.

11:13 am
easyJet plc (EZJ:LSE): Last: 1,013, up 18.5 (+1.86%), High: 1,030, Low: 988.00, Volume: 2.51m
PM

What's the story?

BE

Currently checking out a market rumour -- I stress a rumour -- that there's a bit of quiet stake building going on.

11:14 am
PM

Blimey

BE

The name we've heard is Etihad. And I stress, it's a market rumour.

BE

But it kinda makes sense.

11:15 am
PM

Even if it is raw

BE

Note that Etihad aready has stakes in Air Berlin, Alitalia, Air Serbia, Air Seychelles, Darwin Airline, Jet Airways and Virgin Australia

PM

Why?

11:16 am
BE

The alliance model is quite convenient if you want to shunt people via Dubai

BE

There's also shared ground costs at hub airports and stuff like that.

PM

(It can be irritating to customers. I thought I'd booked BA to NYC last week; found myself on American Airlines. Awful)

11:17 am
BE

Though Emirates, rather than Etihad, has long been seen as EasyJet's most likely partner.

BE

There was a De Telegraaf story last year that Emirates and EasyJet were talking about cooperation at common airports including Amsterdam Schiphol

BE

And that Emirates is in half of EasyJet's 26 European bases.

11:17 am
BE

(I don't have the same figures to hand for Etihad, sorry.)

BE

Also note also that Etihad's out meeting folk right now. As in, right now.

BE

http://www.reuters...ukuk-idUSKBN1321OA

11:18 am
BE

Anyway. We're checking the rumour out. If we can stand it up or knock it down in the next 15 minutes, we'll tell you.

undefined
BE

And, given the lack of anything else to talk about, onto results.

11:18 am
Marks and Spencer Group PLC (MKS:LSE): Last: 343.17, down 5.83 (-1.67%), High: 356.60, Low: 339.60, Volume: 8.21m
BE

Started up then went down.

BE

PBT beats, strategy's .... well, it's typically M&S.

11:19 am
BE

As in, it'll take ages and consume a mountain of cash to do very very little.

BE

The headlines are for a closure of 10% of UK Clothing & Home space

PM

Ouch

11:20 am
BE

Plus "rebalancing" of an incremental 15% (which I think means putting ready meals into it).

PM

Ouch

BE

At a cost of £350m, of which about half is cash, and a delivery date of some time around 2021 or 2022.

11:21 am
PM

(Yes Residual, mandatory bid level, unless you get a Panel whitewash)

PM

Welcome to Markets Live on US election day

BE

Because it's M&S. Their aim of getting to 2022 has to factor in that they're starting in 1987.

11:22 am
PM

M&S been restructuring and rebalancing since I entered financial journalism

BE

On that theme, we have another international retreat.

PM

Again!

11:23 am
BE

Yes! Closure of 10 owned International stores. They're in and out of Europe more than ... actually, I'll not use that simile in these sensitive times ......

BE

Exiting at a cost of £150-200m, of which the “vast majority” will be cash.

BE

To get rid of ten shops that last year lost £45m.

11:24 am
BE

There's a book to be written about M&S's bipolar international ambitions. Probably a comedy.

BE

The upshot of all this is that cash returns are shelved.

PM

It's cut the dividend?

11:25 am
PM

No final?

BE

No -- but it indicated a while back that it was so cash generative that it would be doing special dividends rather than fixing the business.

PM

ah, right

11:25 am
BE

Here's Morgan Stanley. House broker.

BE

And also the broker that's been arguing for some time that M&S should spin off its food business and let the rest die quietly.

BE

(I paraphrase. But only a bit.)

11:26 am
BE

- Today's statement contains an unusually large amount of "new news". Some
aspects are likely to be seen as disappointing by investors (the lack of H2 Special
Dividend, the -0.9% Food LfL in Q2, the downgraded clothing and home gross
margin guidance). However, we think they are likely to be outweighed by positive
developments (the H1 profit beat, the -2.9% Q2 LfL in Clothing & Home, the
decision to exit 10 international markets and reduce the number of 'full line'
stores by c20%). Although there are a number of moving parts, we do not expect
consensus full year forecasts to change much today.

BE

- FY H1 Pre Tax Profits have come in at £231m. Although down 19% on the prior
year, this outcome is better than market expectations (consensus was looking for
£218m).

BE

- M&S did not publish a pre-close statement so the sales figures for FY Q2 are
also 'n ew news' today. Food LfL has come in at -0.9% (versus consensus of flat)
but we believe it is likely to attract relatively little attention today. We would
expect far more focus on the Clothing & Home LfL, which came in at -2.9% in FY
Q2. This compares with a consensus figure of -3.9% and is a marked improvement
on the -8.9% reported in FYQ1.

11:27 am
BE

- Unusually the company has not provided any outlook statement or
commentary at all. However with the comparative base in FY Q3 some 600bps
softer than FY Q2 (on a 3 year 'stacked' basis), we remain hopeful that M&S will
deliver a positive Clothing & Home LfL over the key festive season.
- Much of the focus today, however, is likely to be on company strategy. In
recent weeks the press had suggested that there was likely to be some
downsizing of the company-owned international operations. However, today's
statement goes much further than we believe most investors were anticipating,
with M&S (subject to staff consultations) planning to close all of its stores in 10
of the 13 international markets from which it trades on a company-owned (as
opposed to franchise) basis. This is likely to cost M&S £150-£200m in
exceptional charges (mostly cash, rather than asset writedowns), but should
allow M&S to eliminate £45m of annual losses (though these operations will not
be treated as 'discontinued' until the stores close, so the losses are likely to
remain in headline profit figures for the next 12-18 months).

BE

- Probably the most headline-grabbing news today, however, relates to the UK
store estate. Via a combination of store closures, downsizings and relocations,
M&S intends to reduce the number of 'full line' stores selling both Clothing and
Food by 20% over the next five years. Most of these will be smaller stores, but
nevertheless, Clothing & Home space is expected to fall by c10% (or around 1.2m
square feet). This too is expected to involve significant exceptional costs (£350m),
though these are likely to be incurred gradually over the next five years and
more than half are expected to be 'n on cash'.
- Because of the scale of exceptional charges, M&S has decided not to pay a
special dividend for FY H2. This may disappoint some investors (the company
paid a 4.6p per share special dividend in FY H1 and it was widely anticipated that
it would make a similar distribution in FY H2). However we see this decision as
being directly related to the international downsizing strategy that is being
announced today, which is much more aggressive than we (or we believe most
other commentators) anticipated.

BE

- Although there are a number of moving parts (including a reduction in full year
gross margin guidance for the Clothing & Home division from +50-100bps to
flat-+50bps), we would not anticipate much change in consensus full year profit
forecasts today. According to Bloomberg the Median consensus Pre Tax Profit
expectation for FY 2016/17 is currently £600m (giving EPS of 29.8p).
- Based on existing consensus forecasts and last night's closing price, M&S is
trading on 11.8x Cal 2017e earnings,5.9x EBITDA with a 5.6% Dividend Yield. This
compares with the UK General Retail sector trading on 12.6x, 7.7x and 3.9%
respectively.

11:27 am
BE

Or for a pithier take, Jefferies.

BE

Conclusion: Pushing water up hill? These intentions, in addition to M&S' already announced plans to cut 525 head office jobs and change pay & pensions, highlight the huge job M&S has to do to improve profitability. Given our bearish view on UK consumer confidence and future clothing spend we hope that M&S' five-year recovery strategy will be a case of "two steps forward, one step back" but fear it may be "one step forward, two steps back". Understandably, M&S has put its strategy of additional cash returns to shareholders on hold (at least for 2H17E) though remains committed to being a cash generative business. Trading on c.12x consensus EPS for cal 2017 and 2018, and more than that on our below consensus estimates we remain at Underperform.

BE

Or for a ... what's a positive antonym of pithy? Anyway, here's Clive Black.

11:30 am
BE

With hindsight, we probably should have stood back from our positive stance on M&S stock at the completion of phase I of the strategic thinking updates in the late spring, knowing that the property and international assessments were coming down the line and that they would potentially lead to some uncertainty. Whilst so, we remain of the view that Mr. Rowe is the right man for the job and we do not like ebbing & flowing with our stock recommendations.
However, even within this context, in light of the new guidance on the group's current financial year and the more medium-term prospects following today's update, we have to place our financial forecasts for M&S under review so that we have the opportunity to make some considered assessment of future projections; we need to make an assessment of what the space changes in the UK mean for ongoing revenues as we do for the sales profile internationally with the forthcoming changes announced today. Additionally, noting the current year adjustments, we need to take a considered view of ongoing gross margin trends given management’s determination to be more competitive set against sterling’s devaluation. Having made this point, we reiterate an expectation of a flat final
FY2017 DPS.

BE

That said, we are encouraged by the steps to deal with management accountability and the group operating cost base, noting the summer announcements on central overhead reductions, the operational steps to improve the performance of C&H in the UK, which have very favourable comparatives ahead, the desire to build upon the recent successes in Food and the decision to deal with the ongoing profit and capital requirements from M&S international.
Collectively, all of this work should, to our minds, positively bear fruit at the operating level, so potentially returning M&S to annual and sequential EBIT growth. More broadly, the stated capital discipline within the business also makes for ongoing scope for M&S to drive free cash generation if ongoing volume growth can be delivered, that we believe is the best basis to sustain and grow the dividend per share, strengthen the balance sheet and so reconsider further 'shareholder friendly' initiatives.
Such a narrative has, unfortunately, been more of something for the horizon rather than the near-term viewing from the company for some time as M&S has failed to deliver growth-on-growth in C&H in the UK whilst it has also been geared up for internationalisation that, for a variety of reasons not least of which are outside the company's control, in a macro-political sense, has not worked nor, indeed, indicated light at the end of the tunnel.
Accordingly, whilst not wishing to be starting from the position that he inherited, Steve Rowe is dealing with the reality of M&S in a considered but also decisive manner to our minds. We believe that the component parts of his plan have individual and collective merit and as such do prime M&S for a brighter more profitable. Whilst so, given that we have necessarily placed our financial forecasts under review, given the aforementioned number of moving parts, we must also put our prevailing Buy recommendation in the same place until we have greater clarity as to the quantum of medium-term financial expectations. We do so; however, in a firmly supportive context for management and the new strategy it should be said albeit the numbers will out.

undefined
11:31 am
BE

Paul's swearing at stuff so I'll continue solo for a bit.

PM

(Sorry)

BE

Elsewhere in retail, we have Sports Direct.

11:31 am
Sports Direct International PLC (SPD:LSE): Last: 314.70, down 10.3 (-3.17%), High: 330.00, Low: 313.30, Volume: 457.36k
BE

Perhaps the worst feltcollaredsource 'd company the public markets have ever seen.

PM

11:33 am
BE

The Board understands that at an impromptu open session arranged for the workforce to share their views with the MPs in the afternoon many workers expressed their dissatisfaction with how the Company was portrayed by the Committee and the media.

As such, the Board is disappointed that reporting of a possible recording device (the veracity of which has yet to be determined) has overshadowed the truly important issues that this visit should have focused on - the true working conditions and worker satisfaction at Shirebrook.

The Board would like to make it clear that it did not authorise or have any knowledge of the possible recording device.

BE

I mean ...........

BE

http://www.investe...1611080852255952O/

11:34 am
BE

The Board had no knowledge of the "possible recording device" .......

BE

... There are only two executive folk on the Board!

BE

And one of them wasn't in the building, as the start of the RNS explains in unnecessary detail!

11:35 am
BE

How did Powerscourt let this kind of statement ........ Oh, hang on ......

BE

KBA PR

Keith Bishop

T. 020 7734 9995

BE

Never mind.

11:35 am
undefined
BE

Otherwise in results ..............

Imperial Brands PLC (IMB:LSE): Last: 3,713, down 90 (-2.37%), High: 3,749, Low: 3,649, Volume: 1.57m
11:36 am
PM

http://www.investe...1611080700085802O/

BE

The brand ownership company formerly known as Imperial Tobacco whose brands are all tobacco brands.

PM

I thought the figs were good. Others clearly disagree

11:37 am
BE

Well, headline's fine. Guidance is weird though, and underlying it's less great.

BE

You've also got a (mostly expected) cost saving plan being offset by a (largely unexpected) R&D plan.

BE

Meaning 2017 isn't going to be the turning-point year for cash etc.

11:39 am
BE

Here's RBC.

BE

Imperial Brands reported FY16 adjusted EPS of 249.6 pence, 2% ahead of consensus at 245.4 pence, on the back of total adjusted operating profit of £3,536m (1% ahead
of consensus) and net revenue of £7,916, in line with consensus. Organic revenue for the full year was flat, on the back of underlying volumes down 7.2%, or 5.7%
excluding the impact of Iraq and Syria. That implies 5.3% volume decline and 3.9% price mix in H2.
Guidance indicates that there will be a 4% hit to net income in 2017, a function of increased revenue investment of £300m (net £200m) partly offset by a new (we think)
series of cost savings of £90m. In aggregate this new cost saving programme is expected to yield £300m of annual savings by 2020 (3.75% of sales) at a total
restructuring cost of £750m (£190m per annum, or 2.3% of sales).
The company flagged a good performance of the acquired US assets with both Winston and Kool growing share. Imperial also confirmed its guidance for dividend
growth of at least 10%.

BE

Or Goldman, if you prefer.

11:40 am
BE

News
This morning Imperial reported its FY16 results. Total tobacco volumes
came in at 277 bn (+1% vs GSe and -1% vs Vuma consensus). Total tobacco
net revenue of £7,167 mn was in line with consensus and was +1% vs GSe.
Total tobacco adjusted operating profit reached £3,360 mn (vs consensus
expectations of £3,345 mn, GSe of £3,310 mn). Adjusted EPS came in 2%
ahead of both consensus and GSe. Management’s outlook statement
includes an investment of £300 mn in FY17 (or £200 mn net of investment
returns), offset by £90 mn in savings, resulting in a net (negative) impact to
earnings of 4%. Guidance on FX translation in FY17 is for a 14% benefit to
earnings at current rates. Management also unveiled another phase of the
cost-optimisation programme with an additional £300 mn of annual
savings by 2020, at a cost of £750 mn.

BE

Analysis
Based on current Reuters consensus adjusted EPS (FY17E) of 281.3p,
estimates imply 12.7% earnings growth. Based on management’s growth
guidance of +14% from FX and -4% from investments, estimates imply
+2.7% of ‘organic’ earnings growth in FY17E, which we regard as
undemanding. Our current forecast of 287.1p is 2% above Reuters
consensus estimates.
The shares have underperformed the European staples sector, down 10.6%
over the last three months (in euros) vs the staples sector down 7.4%. We
expect there could be an initial negative reaction to the announced £300
mn investment by management in FY17; however, with consensus
expectations remaining relatively undemanding, we see any weakness
being short-lived.

BE

(They're buyers, of course.)

11:41 am
undefined
BE

(@Chopper: the terrible Tawke production numbers at the back of October probably didn't help.)

BE

We promised a half session but it seems we're still running.

11:44 am
BE

Let me see what we've still to cover. There's Lancashire ......

BE

.......... Second downgrade in two days. Bernstein yesterday ....

BE

...... which I had no space whatsoever to cover in the paper overnight, unfortunately, so didn't do it justice.

11:46 am
BE

Lancashire: Fundamentals, Dividend and M&A not worth more than GBp700; downgrade to Underperform

BE

Capital levels are already down to within Lancashire's target range of $1.35-1.4bn and
dividend pay-out ratios in the future (without growth or large losses) can come up to 100% of earnings, but not to the above 100%-levels seen in recent years when business shrunk a lot. M&A probability is not high enough to justify the current premium to our Target Price. Peers
have been acquired for as much as 2.4x tangible book, which would imply a valuation for
Lancashire of up to GBp1,000. But Lancashire is less diversified than peers, has higher key
man risk and is more exposed to current pricing pressure in Reinsurance and Energy, which deters buyers in our view. We see less than 20% chance of a bid emerging near-term.

BE

That's the upshot. Contact Bernstein for the rest.

11:47 am
BE

UBS follows today, with ......

BE

Turning more cautious on the sub-sector; downgrading Lancashire to Sell

The London Market insurers' ROEs are under pressure, COEs have fallen as track

records improved and valuations look elevated. This means earnings growth is critical to

support premium valuations. However, key growth areas are increasingly in longer tail /

less diversifying lines which are consuming more capital, eroding dividend potential.

With the sub-sector still well owned for dividend yields, we think something's got to

give. Our work suggests Hiscox and Beazley can grow earnings enough to support

valuations, but capital required to grow removes scope for even small specials, capping

yields at c3-3.5% from FY17E, perhaps not enough to draw the marginal buyer. We

estimate Lancashire can yield 6-7% from FY17E, but there is no EPS growth; absent this

we struggle to justify paying 1.4xTNAV given it is under most pricing pressure vs. peers.

We downgrade to Sell after a good run.

BE

We find no compelling dividend stories amongst the London Market insurers

Beazley and Hiscox's growth in commercial / casualty lines is less diversifying than it was

and a longer tail bias is pushing capital requirements up. We model FY15-20E GWP

growth of c5-6%, but growth in capital requirements of 5-8%. Our modelling shows

FCF pay-out ratios of c80-100% based on ordinary dividends alone; we find limited FCF

flexibility and, absent specials, ordinary yields are low. Conversely, we expect capital

requirements to shrink at Lancashire as its book remains under pressure. This suggests

it can pay out slightly more than 100% of FCF yielding 6-7%. Whilst attractive, we

doubt the economics of paying 1.4xTNAV for money to be returned at face whilst

TNAV shrinks.

11:48 am
BE

The low return hurdles of recent acquirers is a risk to us turning more cautious

Recent M&A highlights that some investors are willing to apply lower discount rates in

the hunt for returns in a low yield world. Market implied COE for London Market

insurers is c6.5-8.5%. The implied COE in some recent deals is as low as 5%. We still

think COE is higher than this, given the inherent volatility of reinsurance business.

Applying a conservative 10% COE implies current valuations are pricing in 5-10%

earnings growth which looks broadly achievable at HSX and BEZ, but not at Lancashire

where we expect earnings to contract by 6%. We think a COE as low as 5% is needed

to justify Lancashire's valuation, suggesting bid support is already priced in.

BE

(Reminded that we went code red at the start of last month on a rumour about an overseas insurer buying a UK-focused one .... )

BE

(Turned out to be this: http://asia.nikkei...er-for-about-6.5bn )

11:50 am
undefined
BE

(@Lemmy: absolutely nothing on that. Seriously, nothing whatsoever. I'd suggest exercising extreme caution around that particular rumourtrage.)

BE

We promised you a short session so let's make it a short session, so we can all get back to our real lives.

11:53 am
BE

Thanks for joining. And let's just hope we've a website to come back to tomorrow morning.

BE

See you then.

PM

Why so long?
